summary.seg: This folio manuscript is Pembroke College’s Benefactors’ Book, a great work of seventeenth-century bibliography. Its largest section is an illustrated register of donors to Pembroke’s library, supplying the books that donors gave alongside their biographies and arms. It was begun in 1617 by Matthew Wren, uncle of the architect Christopher, who was Pembroke’s President at the time.

Wren first listed all the previous gifts of books for which he could find evidence. Then he began entering gifts made to the library during his own tenure, of which the largest by far came from Lancelot Andrewes, Master of the College. (Have a look at his beautifully painted arms on f. 92r.) After Wren left Pembroke in 1624, other members of Pembroke continued making entries as new donations came in. This practice continued until the early eighteenth century.

Nearly every seventeenth-century college in Oxford and Cambridge used a book like Wren’s to commemorate its library’s benefactors, following the lead of the Bodleian Library and All Souls College. Many of these books were beautifully illustrated; in fact some of them are now the most lavish post-medieval manuscripts in their respective colleges’ collections. Matthew Wren’s book was part of the broader fad for these books, and in that sense it was not unique.

Nevertheless, it is set apart from all other college benefactors’ books by its scholarly quality. Wren’s long introduction to the book told the library’s history from its medieval beginnings down to his own day. To tell that story Wren cited letters, statutes and receipts from the College’s archives, few of which still survive. At the end of the Benefactors’ Book, meanwhile, Wren drew up Pembroke’s first systematic catalogue of manuscripts, which he had already ranged into an alphabetical series. Taken all together, Wren’s scholarship in this book gives us valuable insight into the workings of Pembroke’s early-modern library.

M. R. James included a small extract from the book in his 1905 catalogue of Pembroke College’s manuscripts. About a century later, the Cambridge volume of the Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues printed part of Wren’s record on medieval gifts, cataloguing its extract as UC47. Here the book has been digitised and transcribed for the first time.
Note to readers: folios 201v-296r, 316v-325r and 327v - all blank leaves/pages - were not photographed during the manuscript's digitisation and consequently are not displayed on the Digital Library.

msItem.title: Matthew Wren's Benefactors' Book
Memoriae, veritati, virtuti, sacram laurum Pembrochianam...

support.material: Paper, with five leaves of parchment (1-3, 5-6)

supportDesc.extent: ix + 315 + xii leaves (foliated i-ix, 1-327). A small scrap of paper bearing contemporary writing, kept between folios 26 and 27, has been foliated as 26a. 335 215
supportDesc.collation: The binding of the volume is too tight to determine the collation. The incidence of watermarks in the paper stocks might be adduced in order to determine the structure of the quires, however this awaits full description and analysis.

foliation.p: The manuscript has been refoliated, however at the time of writing the new numbering has not been written into the manuscript. The first parchment leaf has been numbered 1 and all leaves following thereafter have been numbered in sequence, including the endleaves at the rear of the volume.

The two separate, imperfect and incomplete sequences of foliation written in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side, completed apparently by Matthew Wren and contemporary with the copying of the manuscript, have now been cancelled and should not be cited.

bindingDesc.p: 17th century gold-tooled, dark-brown morocco, probably executed by the Centre Rectangle Binder in Cambridge; two concentric panels decorated with tulips, corner fleurons and a centre ornament consisting of stars, moons and suns; gold-tooled border and cover edges decorated with arabesque designs. Restored in 2006 by the generosity of Tony and Christine Wilkinson.

provenance.p: Printed bookplate of Pembroke College, Cambridge, dated 1700.

div.p:
There is probably no portion of the history of our earlier colleges
which is more interesting than that of their libraries. None which
better deserves and will more richly repay a close investigation.
Founded for the purposes of study, we are naturally interested in the
inquiry what were the chief pursuits [?] of their inhabitants, to
what departments in the domain of knowledge they chiefly dedi-
cated their minds, what books they read, to what studies they were
devoted – This inquiry we are able to answer
to a certain extent by our examination of the ancient-catalogues of the
Libraries existing in some of our earlier foundations. – One such
relating to St Cath: Hall was published a few years since by I**
Corrie, and is of no small interest. But no college is more
fortunate in this respect than Pembroke which possesses an elabo-
rate MS. history of the library & Catalogue of the books which it *** had
contained, **** by Matthew Wren, Bp of
Norwich & Ely, formerly fellow of the House, and founder of the
present chapel of the college, built by his nephew Sir C Wren
after his decease On this interesting document I propose to
offer a few remarks.

The volume in question is a bulky folio bound in dark green
Morocco, and bearing the date 1617. At the commencement of the
colume is emblazoned a tree, represented by a strange misapprehension
in the
Nomina eorum qui Bibliothecæ huic donaria

Integerrimo, piissimoque Præsuli,
Diïo Nicolao Felton, D. provi-
dentiâ Episcopo Bristoliensi,
Aulæ nostræ Pembrochianæ
Reverendissimo Præfecto, Virisque
cæteris præclarissimis, ejusdem
Collegii Sociis
M. W. in humanis omnibus atque
Divinis εὖ πράττειν.

Habetis hic, Colendissimi Viri, otiorum meorum aliquam rati-
onem. Quid præstiterim, vestrum est arbitrari, ego quod navârim,
prorsus non nescio. Vos, si alicujus in majores nostros gratitudinis,
in almam Matrem Pietatis, in vos Officii, in posteros invitamenti,
non ineptum institutum esse censeatis, abundè est mihi. Audiat enim
Fides, audiat Veritas, illas ego res jamdio ago præ meis. Quod vos
appellem verò, suasit etiam alterius consilii ratio. Pergendum sit necne
mihi, atque ab istâ Bibliothecali opellâ ad aliquot alia rerum nostra-
rum capitula transeundum, apud me non invenio quod statuam, vos
potestis decernere. Vester enim sum, vestræ, Reverendissime Custos,
egregiæ Dominationis, vestræ, Literatissimi Socii, eximiæ Dignitatis
omnibus cum Officiis Observantissimus. Deum supplex posco, Fœlices
vivatis, Pembrochianique (quod facitis) nominis gloriam Æternitati
porrò commendetis. Valete.

Lector,
Si vacat, et res nostras libentèr audis,
est quod te velim. Bibliothecam hanc,
quam spectas, nec ab Aulâ Conditâ
extitisse, nec primævos tamen Socios
libris Publicis omnino caruisse, ex me
disce; Antiquissimorum Statutorum ista vox est:

Sit in dicta Domo unus Custos librorum, qui omnes libros communitatis ad
Custodiam suam recipiat, et quotannis semel, viz. in Festo Translationis Sti Thomæ
Martyris, vel ad ultimam intra octavas sequentes calculum communitati reddat de iisdem,
singulos Custodi et Sociis per ordinem ostendendo. Quibus visis, præmissâ
deliberatione Sociorum, unicuique juxta competentiam suae necessitatis distribuat.
Et habeat idem Custos Tabulas magnas dispositas cum cerâ et pergameno,
ut in pergameno scribantur nomina librorum, et in cerâ respondente nomina.
Sociorum possidentium libros, qui cùm retradiderint, nominibus suis ablatis,
de libris excusentur, Custode remanente onerato, ne sit incertius de libro vel
possesore. Nullus insuper liber communis extra Domum quocunque
colore alienetur seu accomodetur, nisi forte in casu, quo Majori parti Com-
munitatis videbitur expediens: et tum si liber aliquis debeat accomodari,
fiat sub cautione idoneâ Custodi librorum expositâ sine fraude.

Sapis scio, et his pellectis, satis ipse per
te observas, etsi nullus moneam, quis usus
hic et ordo fuerit, quæ cura atque Custodia li-
brorum jam inde à principio. Habuisse
tamen vel tum, vel non longè posteà, locum
aliquem publicum, ubi libri reponerentur, nolo
dubites, cum ejus rei mentionem in archivis
subinde reperiam.

Cujus planè auspiciis, clara quidem res
non est; ego, quæ reperi, expono, tuum esto
judicium. Occurrit primò Epistola, quam
tu (credo) grandem utcunque, et (quod est de-
terius) nominum etiam et temporis luce
carentem, integrè tamen huc transcriptam
non iniquè feres, propter tum illius ætatis
stylum, tum hujus Quæsiti non leve argu-

Immensâ siquidem Omnipotentis Dei Pietate, secretoque consilio Paracliti Spiritus clementem il-
lum et fidelem Mardocheum Sacra testatur historia à patriis subtractum domibus in regis Assueri
Curiam et obsequium familiare pervenisse. Quod quidem eò factum fuisse satis aptè putamus,
ut quotiens innocentissima Judæorum concio injuriis lacessita succumberet, aut rursus necessitatem
haberet quippiam à rege misericorditèr postulandi simul ac impetrandi, ipse tanquam eorum
cœlestis advocatus piis supplicantium votis benignissimi regis animum inclinaret. Quo qui-
dem pacto in singularem gratiam illustrissimi Regis nostri arbitramur Dominationem
Vestram supernâ vocatione susceptam, ut vestris favoribus et clementissimâ mediatione
Pauperes et longè positi à Benignissimo Rege nostro id pietatis et misericordiæ munus
gratiosè optineant. Ea propter (Egregie Domine et Magister Honoratissime, nostræ
refugiam senectutis et spei fortitudo) aures clementissimi Regis nostri piis precibus digneris
inclinare, ut inter amplissima munera et dotationem filiæ suæ primogenitæ, et quasi naturalis,
(hoc est, Honorabilis et Domino acceptissimi Collegii sui in Honorem Stæ Dei Genitricis
Mariæ et Sti Confessoris Nicolai fundati et erecti) vel exiguam reservare dignetur benedictio-
nem ad eam filiam, (humillimum collegium suum de Penbrok loquor) quam mise^ricorditèr
suam fecit titulo adoptionis. Nam cum jam deinceps ad fabricam novæ librariæ supra Aulam
dicti Collegii (propitio Domino) manus apponere decrevimus factrices, profectò adoptivæ filiæ
suæ, quæ tamen justissimè sua est, singularem gratiam conferre poterit et munificentiæ

largitatem ad expensas ferendas æquanimitèr, si sua dignetur Regalis et excellentissi-
ma Benignitas Lxxx valentes quercus ad ejusdem pauperis atque humillimæ Adoptivæ
suæ augendam dotem misericorditèr elargiri. Quapropter cum Venerabilis vir Mr., et Custos
Collegii nostri (qui satis solicitè nostra hactenus consuevit negotia procurare, atque præter hoc in in-
stanti necessitate habundantèr copioseque promiserit ex innatâ sibi liberalitate ad fœlicem promotionem
operis antedicti) totus intentus sit et observiat prosperæ educationi et dotationi magnificæ filiæ Sere-
nissimi Regis nostri primogenitæ et quasi naturalis, adeò ut ejus defessar cervices et fatigabiles
artus amplioribus onerare sarcinis ab officio Pietatis longè putemus alienum; Hoc solum
advenimus pro refugio singulari, et nostrorum captandâ spe votorum, ut vestram devotissimè
interpellemus Dominationem, quam præter merita gratissimam nobis sæpè persensimus; Quatenus
ipsam sæpiùs antedictam filiam adoptivam in auribus Christianissimi Regis nostri di-
gneris pro Domino in hac re effectualitèr habere commendatam. Nec vestram quæsumus
aliquatenus moveat Clementiam, aut notam faciat temerariæ præsumptionis, quòd has
literas nostras pauperrimas quasi incultis animis seu spiritu præsumpto V. Reverentiis
destinaverimus; Cùm quanta præstiterit V. Dominationis caritas et affectus sinceræ
devotionis ad nostrum pauperrimum Collegium, (cujus adeptam gratiam et honoris com-
meriti titulum magnâ ex parte arbitramur sub Deo ex V. Honoribus et Dignissimâ
laude resudasse) in rebus gravioribus sæpissimè effecti sumus certiores. Pro quibus equi-
dem, quoniam permulta sunt, nec nostro sermone facile coartanda, in Deum totum
refundimus, et piis interpellamus lacrymis immensam ejus Clementiam congruas et con-
dignas rependere vices in gaudiis beatorum, Qui pro modicis magna, pro transitoriis sem-
piterna, et pro terrenis cœlestia præmia dignatus est fœlicitèr commutare, Jesus Christus
Deus et Dominus noster. Amen. Script. Cantabr. 2do Novembr. etc.

Ædificavit etiam Bibliothecam Communem Collegii.
Igitur pergo; Aoque rursus 1462 aliquid in
libraria innovatum fuisse quatuor librarum
sumptu, Ais verò 1550, et 1551 aliarum de-
cem librarum, idque è cistâ communi: sed Ao
demum 1617 Bibliothecam hanc totam immu-
tatam longè fuisse, atque novam ominò faciem
induisse, admonitum porrò te volo.
Quid causæ quæris? An cujus impensis? U-
trumque expedio. In causâ fuit librorum gran-
de detrimentum, quod cepisse eos jam, et
capere indies, summo cum dolore persensimus,
tum ex declivi pluteorum fabricâ, tum ex in-
eptâ mole catenarum. Ut subveniatur itaque o-
rant Socii, annuit atque instat R.dus Custos,
Præses formam invenit, opus cum illo curant
Thesaurii.
At sumptuum intereà onere levatur Collegium

Decurrenda sunt adhuc alia.
Emptos à Collegio nonnullos libros,
suisque sibi sumptibus paratos, ut et
venditos etiam alios interdum fuisse, non
potest dubitari. Hac de re tamen pau-
cissima sunt, quæ à me reperta ipsorum
non ordine solùm, sed et verbis etiam (ut-
cunque) audies.

There is probably no portion of the history of our earlier colleges
which is more interesting than that of their libraries. None which
better deserves and will more richly repay a close investigation.
Founded for the purposes of study, we are naturally interested in the
inquiry what were the chief pursuits [?] of their inhabitants, to
what departments in the domain of knowledge they chiefly dedi-
cated their minds, what books they read, to what studies they were
devoted – This inquiry we are able to answer
to a certain extent by our examination of the ancient-catalogues of the
Libraries existing in some of our earlier foundations. – One such
relating to St Cath: Hall was published a few years since by I**
Corrie, and is of no small interest. But no college is more
fortunate in this respect than Pembroke which possesses an elabo-
rate MS. history of the library & Catalogue of the books which it *** had
contained, **** by Matthew Wren, Bp of
Norwich & Ely, formerly fellow of the House, and founder of the
present chapel of the college, built by his nephew Sir C Wren
after his decease On this interesting document I propose to
offer a few remarks.

The volume in question is a bulky folio bound in dark green
Morocco, and bearing the date 1617. At the commencement of the
colume is emblazoned a tree, represented by a strange misapprehension
in the

In witness of his piety, his gratitude and his duty, Matthew Wren, devoted to Pembroke College, established this Laurel of Pembroke, dedicated to memory, truth, and virtue; and inscribed with the names of men who made gifts to this library.
Student, Fellow, and President Matthew Wren, Bachelor of Sacred Theology

Matthew Wren, Fellow of Pembroke College, to the honourable and most pious Master, Nicholas Felton, the Bishop of Bristol by the providence of God; to the most reverend Prefect of our Pembroke Hall; and to other distinguished men,
wishing them to prosper in all human and divine affairs.

Here, most distinguished men, is some explanation of my endeavours. Whether I have done it worthily is for you to judge; I for one doubt not but that I have done it diligently. It is enough for me if you think that this was done aptly as a bit of thanksgiving to our forebears, of devotion to our alma mater, of duty to you, and of an encouragement to posterity. With faith and truth as my witnesses, I care for these things more than for my own affairs. I address you now with a second plan in mind. I do not know, and you can judge, whether I ought to continue, and whether after this work on the library I ought to go on to some other subjects touching the college. For I am all yours. I am, most reverend Master, a scrupulous and devoted guardian of your excellent rule; and, most learned fellows, of your great learning. I beseech God that you might live happily, and that (as you are doing) you might continue to commit the glory of the name of Pembroke to Eternity. Farewell. 1 January 1617.

If you are at liberty, and willingly attend to my argument, then I am satisfied. Learn from me that this Library which you see did not exist from the founding of the College; that, nevertheless, the earliest Fellows by no means lacked common books. This is to be found in the earliest statutes:

There shall be in said Hall a warden of books, who shall take all of the community's books into his care, and once a year (on the Feast of the Translation of St Thomas the Martyr, or until the last day of the following octave), he will render an account of them to the community, showing each one to the Warden and the Fellows by rank. When the books have been seen, after a discussion among the Fellows, the warden of books shall distribute them to each fellow according to his needs.

And the same warden shall have large tablets set up in both wax and parchment, so that the names of books might be written on the parchment and the corresponding names in the wax. When fellows return the books they have possessed, their names shall be erased from the wax and they shall be relieved of the books, the warden taking on responsibility for them, in order to remove any doubt as to the book or its possessor. Besides, no common book is to be removed or lent out from the College for any reason, unless it seem expedient to a majority of the community: and in that case, if a book must be lent, it should be done against an appropriate pledge in plain view of the warden of the books.

You are clever enough, I know, to observe from this without my prodding what the order and customs of this library were, and what care and watchfulness there was for the books from the beginning. Doubt neither that there was then – though not for long – a public place for books to be stored. I have found mention of this in the archives, which I reproduce here:
1423. For timber [meremium]x bought for the library at the market, 9s.
The same year, for carting the library’s wood to the shore, 3d.
1425 & 1428. For chains and other iron, 9s. 9 d
1433. Received from a certain person for the library, £4. Then
1436. For the repair of glass in the library, 2s.4d

p.hi: Though it appears a hundred times, I confess that I haven't figured out what this means.

div.p: [Thomas Gray, in English]: Meremium is Timber, Wood.

After Lawrence Booth became master of this Hall, it was not long before the Muses stored their arsenal in that very place. Booth was an extrordinary man, who was never too much or enough remembered (indeed, who cannot be enough remembered). Godwilling we will say more about him in his place.

As to what happened under his watch, the evidences by no means plain, but I will lay out what I have found, and you shall be the judge. First there is a letter which you will, I think, consider lofty and (what's worse) wanting clues about its date and author. But you won't think it wrong to see it transcribed entire here, both because of the style of its age and because of the evidence it brings to bear on our inquiry. It runs thus:

The holy scripture records that, by the great faithfulness of Almighty God and the secret help of the Holy Ghost, the merciful and faithful Mordecai, driven from his native house, was raised to the court of King Ahasuerus on friendly terms. We judge that this was so done that whenever the innocent community of Jews should stagger under the outrages raised against it, or should need no sooner to ask something meekly from the king than to recieve it; Mordecai, as if their heavenly advocate, might sway the attention of the good-willed king to the pious wishes of the beseeching Jews. In the same way, we believe your Lordship was by a heavenly mandate so called into the special grace of our most illustrious King, that by your partiality and most merciful mediation, some poor ones standing far off from the most Benevolent King might gratefully recieve his token of piety and mercy. For that reason (excellent Lord and most honoured master, our shelter in old age and strength of our hope) deign to bend the ears of the most merciful King to your pious prayers, so that alongside the ample riches and dowry of his firstborn and natural daughter (that is, his honourable and God-beloved College founded and built in honour of the Holy Mother of God and St Nicholas the Confessor [King's College]), he might also deign to reserve even a mean blessing to that daughter (his most humble Pembroke College) which he mercifully made his by adoption. Now because we have decided to set craftsmen's hands to the building of a new library above the Hall of said College (with the favor of God) doubtless the King can bestow special grace and generosity on his adopted daughter (who is no less lawfully his) to bear her expenses more easily,

if his Royal and most excellent Mercy only stoops mercifully to enlarge her dowry with eighty strong oaks. Now the Venerable Master and Warden of our College (who heretofore has looked after our affairs rather diligently, and besides, in our present need, has pledged abundently out of his natural generosity to advance the aforesaid project) is completely pledged and devoted to the education and endowment of the Most Serene King's great firstborn and natural daugher, to such an extent that we should think it beyond the bounds of piety to lay more burdens on his tired nape and fatigued limbs. Therefore, we have come up with this as our only refuge, and our hope for the fulfilment of promises to us: that we might devotedly ask your Lordship, whom we have always thought most gracious to us beyond our deserts, to deign to make this oft-mentioned adoptive daughter sincerely favoured in this matter in the ears of the Most Christian King. Nor, we pray, should it trouble Your Mercy at all, or be taken as a mark of rash boldness, that we have sent this poor letter to Your Reverence in a rude mind and a presumptive spirit: for on account of the greatness of Your Lordship's fondness and feeling of sincere devotion to our poor College (whose achieved grace and title of worthy honour has been produced in a large part, we think, by your honours and worthy praise under God), we have often become more confident in weightier matters. Now, since these matters are so many, and not to be easily compressed into a single speech, we pour everything out to God. And with pious tears we appeal to his Mercy to repay us in the joys of the blessed—to Him who has happily deigned to change great things for small things, eternal things for fleeting things, heavenly rewards for earthly rewards: Jesus Christ, our God and Lord. Amen. Cambridge, 2 November etc.

Now, I cannot even guess which man or hero [cf. Horace C.I.12] is addressed here, but I own that I've determined which Warden [i.e. Master] is referred to. He was Lawrence Booth, a man highly favoured by the Most Holy King (in truth the parent of our College), Henry VI. This is plain (not to mention other evidences) from the sequence of events. In 1450, he was chosen Warden and he happily presided in that post for thirty years. What, though, of this library?
The early records record that it was begun two years later, and finished in three. Go to the year 1452, and read:
'Total sum for the new library: £45 – 7s – 4d laid out from the treasury'
(or 'paid', for the reading is difficult). Then, in 1455:
Out of the monies which he has received for the library, we have received 20s. from Mr Gerard.
This was Gerard Skipwith (let me say it somewhere: he was a dear man, if anyone is) who had been entrusted with the care of this building. He himself testified elsewhere,
Gerardus Skipwith: I have received *** for the building of our new Library.

What then? Do you want to know what I think? The King, of course (who was always filled with generosity to this house) made good on his promise, but the other costs were later borne by the magnificent Prefect Booth himself.

Many pieces of evidence support this conclusion. One is the following: in the record of the sum total of expenses, in the aforementioned record of the total sum of expenses, every item is plainly struck through, as if removed from the public accounts. Second, a Boar's Head (Booth's insignia) is painted onto the glass of every window.

Third and finally, in the ancient register in the hands of the Warden, he is said to have repaired the library from his own funds. But most definitively, I copy from the notes of the Reverend of Ely (faithful searcher and fosterer of Pembroke's glories):

p.hi: He also built the College's common library.

div.p: To continue: mark that in 1492, there were new works in the library at the cost of £4. In 1550–1, there was another outlay of £10 from the common treasury. But in 1617 this entire library, which had been unchanged for a long time, was given an entirely new aspect. Why, you ask, and at whose expense? I'll tell you both. The cause was 1) the books' great deterioration, which (we noticed with deep pain) had affected them already, and which was affecting them more day by day; 2) the sloping wood of the shelves; and 3) the unsuitabe pile of chains. Therefore the Fellows pray that the situation be helped. The Reverend Warden has approved and insisted on it. The President is devising a plan, and the Treasurers are working on it with him.
But meanwhile the college is relieved of the burden of costs... [there appears to be a lacuna here.]

A few more matters are to be run through. It cannot be doubted that some books were bought by the college on its own funds, and also that some were occasionally sold. But there are very few examples of this; here is what I've found of the phenomenon, not just in a bare list, but with annotations of various kinds.

The following are donations. A offering to the Library must now be made of the entire Catalogue with its donors. Passing over the expenses from 1417 down to 1577 (they exceed the total of £19, for calf- and sheepskins (to use the archives' words), and for the production, shipment, binding, repair, and inscription of books and stall-tables, etc.), let us now carry out the main business of this work.

What is my evidence, you ask? There is certainly good evidence, which I will be able to prove to you unless you are too ill-willed. I have two sources. One is extremely old and not without its errors; it is stored in College. The more recent one, made by the Reverend of Ely, is somewhat more correct. But I was satisfied with neither one. Ι applied careful study, and by a minute

examination of the archives and each and every book, I finally rooted out the material from which this Catalogue is derived. (Is it perfect? I don't have so proud a brow as to say so, but it is plainly better by half than its sources.) Compare them, if you like, and judge them, for the other is on public view.

It is fitting to begin with the men themselves, and then for the books to be supplied. And though I seem to promise a history of these men, my intention is this, that if anything comes up touching a man who was neither a warden, nor a fellow, nor a benefactor in any way of the library, let me dispense with it here. For I shall deal with these wardens and fellows and benefactors – indeed, with the whole state of the College – separately, with the help of God. But I shall be silent about them now, execept inasmuch as they
bear on the library in particular.
[To say it only once here: unless my eyes were blinded, the books that I have marked with an asterisk are wanting.]

I, J. Somerseth, Citizen of London, and Doctor of Liberal Arts and of conserving human life, give this to the library of Pembroke Hall in Cambridge to be chained there forever. Therefore be the renowned hall blessed in which I was educated as a student, and blessed be its most devoted foundress Lady Mary of St Pol; may she live forever with God. Thanks be to God. 1448. /
I think it this well made and well said.]

If he had left a catalogue of these gifts, he would have kept his extraordinary promise. Besides this, he doubtless gave us a few books that are now unfortunately missing.

I have consulted the catalogue of James (from Oxford). A year had barely passed since this donation, when James counted all the books, finding 191 volumes. But he is not to be trusted, for he often mixed in the gifts of other donors. Conversely, nearly thirty of the books which he lists are certainly missing.

[A pious and righteous man, never far from the Muses who finally gave his entire self to them, especially those of Pembroke. He gave the first three books while he was still alive. On his death he bequeathed £10, out of which the fourth and the six after that were bought, and a good part remains to be spent. He gave all the rest of the books himself. The final seven of these are manuscripts, and products of his own genius. He also gave a fine chest to be placed in the Library, intended to store mathematical instruments which he also bequeathed. Verily he was a worthy man, whom we piously remember, for he truly loved our race. He died in 1612. / The following blank space is to be filled with the books bought on what remains of the money that he left.]
fellow of the College. He gave:
[♣.He gave it in 1609. But some wicked hand has purloined what this extremely poor man donated so piously.]

Thus far, reader, you have whatever I could gather from all of my research about the names and gifts of the men who filled this library. If I should sometime discover that I have omitted any of them, than godwilling I will mark their names down. I hope that Reverend Whitgift will be first in this category, just as he was first in the Church.

Now I entreat God that these entries be an example for posterity. With that intention in mind I ordered so many empty pages to be attached, thus to afford space for recording new names when the time comes. And behold, I am not cheated by this hope.
[Foliation restarts from here, and gives out near the end. JSN]
I continue in the same scheme. I only copy the bare names of Masters and Fellows here; perhaps somewhere else I shall say more about them individually.
[The rest of this page is blank, but Nicholas Felton's coat-of-arms appears on it and the numbering on the next page starts at 2. JSN]
generously gave the following. [He lives in Histon, close to Cambridge. But sixteen years earlier he was among the College's pensioners of the second order.]
[He promises to give the other parts when they are available.] Truly, he is a good man.]

I barely dare to say, however, that I have given these three mss. For they were once Pembroke’s, unless I much mistake. They were certainly stolen and sold, and then found among the books of my deceased friend Thompson. I now pay the price to make them Pembroke’s once more. A Londoner, and once in these halls among the students of Dr Watts. He took the degree of Master of Arts thirty years ago. A man of extraordinary learning, and supremely useful to his country in instructing the youth as best as possible. On 1 August 1618 he gave to this College

Each volume is in Greek, in folio by Stephanus. He also says that he will make this Library the heir of his own library. My best friend will not have promised in vain if God denies him a male child. (I wish him a happy son, one similar to his parent.)
He added a little book that is not easily found, in which you find:
[A citizen of London, kin to Matthew Wren. [Non. Nov. 1618]
8.2.19 corresponds to another, later gift of the same.
Once a student of this College, made Master of Arts seven years ago. Now the Rector of the churches of Kenne, and the bishop of Cheriton in Devonshire.
A musician of Ware, in witness to his gratitude for free lodging afforded him for 31 years, gave:
Fellow of the College. He gave:
Doubtless a learned and finely copied book, albeit with lacunæ here and there. The donor reserved it for his own use for half a year.
From the inscription it seems that he was once a librarian of the College, and that the book once belonged to Thomas Cranmer the Archbishop. I did not come across him earlier, so I am adding him now.
Every sort of writing is to be found which came out of Pembroke’s family. Out of these are the books that are acquire today.

Fellow of the College. He gave: [Jul. 22. 1619]

As a young man, he had been barely made Master of Arts when he was sent more than once on the King's business to Sabaudia and then to Heidelberg. There he was declared the chief secretary of Lady Elizabeth, Princess of the Palatinate. On his return, he was made a knight bachelor and an ordinary clerk in the Senate. (Up to this point he was a fellow of Kings College). He was a man born to great lineage and great deeds. From the very start he was beloved to Pembroke: he would call me 'my blood' and I would call him 'my flesh'.
It is not right to silently pass over acquisitions of books made collectively. Therefore:
The Master and Fellows have remitted all the money which they could have asked from Robert Woodward for the grant of his lodging, besides 26s. 8d., from which were bought:
Mark what the donor himself inscribed:
Thou formest my tender childhood years, O ancient and venerable Hall of Pembroke, who art full of happy spirits. May it at least be allowed to repay a slender part of the great duty I owe to you.
Samuell Crooke, once a scholar of Pembroke Hall.

Upon taking his first degree, he moved to Emmanuel College, and he was made a fellow there twenty years ago. Now as Rector of the Church of [blank], he accomplishes the pious work of the Church by preaching and writing.

um vota, referente. (An extremely elaborate work!)
A Londoner, and a patron of good letters, of which he is not ignorant of all. When he heard that I was striving to fit out out this library, he sent me a plainly extraordinary gift unasked.
[An extremely learned woman, and a true daughter of the Muses.]

A London citizen, and my intimate friend. He always paid much regard to the College, and especially on the admission of a boy of good promise, the brother of his wife (a superb woman). As soon as he saw this work on the library, he at once made over of his own will:

A Merchant and a Senator of Lynn, not yet content with the great witness to his love and adoration for letters and religion that he had given earlier (in the new pulpit of the church of Mary), he caused his name and love to be declared in the treasury of Pembroke's Muses. On 9 October 1621, he therefore gave:
Coloniæ Agrippinæ, sump. A. Hierati et J. Gyminici 1612. fol.

He was a true Pembrokian by his own right, and not by his father's alone (who had been a fellow here forty years ago). After he was taken into that celebrated order of Dr Watt's students, and then admitted to the order of Bachelor, he went over to the court for the sake of educating boys. But it was not long before, once he was a Master of Arts, he came back to our neighbourhood as the head teacher of Perse's school, and, what's more, reestablished himself here with his friendly gift to this library. On 10 November 1621 he gave:
11.2.23–24 or 11.10.9–10 Apud P. & J. Choët, Col. Allob. 1619 fol.
[Citizen and merchant of London, a man filled with pious feeling for letters and the Muses. He benevolently gave:
3.3.25 Coloniæ Agrippinæ ex off. Cholin sump. P. Cholini 1612 fol.
[He made the frontispiece to these with his own hands, using these words:]
Let this golden mouth speak of my love.
I wish this to be a monument to you, dear fellows.
If not now, when? {Hebrew; cf. Pirké Aboth I.14}
O fond Marie, next in worth after the holy virgin Mary,
Though I cannot repay thee, fosteress of Athens
Take with good will your son’s offering of thanks for his nourishment,
Whose poverty keeps him from sufficient piety.
[Gifts to friends] are beyond the reach of fortune. {cf. Martial Ep. 45}

The Herris family is renowned in Essex. One of the eminent Cricksey family, our Herris was the son of William, a knight bachelor. A child of extraordinary character, he was admitted into our hall in 1608 under my care. After three years or thereabout, his kin called him away to municipal administration. But it was not long before he became bored stiff with legal formulæ, and in order to regain the delights of the Academy (which he harboured and which held him fast), he came back to the Muses. A little later, he took his degree in the arts which he had practised so untiringly. A year and a half then went by before he was brought back unwillingly into the patronage of Lord Francis Bacon in the courts of law. He was sorely missed in the Academy. When he was made chancellor to Bacon by decree, he was put in charge of recording ecclesiastical affairs. In this task he clearly proved his fame and faith to all good men. His clean and unbribable soul was neither corrupted by the pollution of his kin, nor zeal for office, nor the unctuousness of the times. Among his great crowd of admirers only Death was found to spurn his ample gifts. For after a few months of decay, he died at the beginning of April 1622. But he did not die without a singular witness to his eternal piety towards Pembroke his parent.

Namely, he took care in his will to leave £10 to be allocated privately by the Warden to a needy student of his choice. He also left £40 to be spent publicly for the use of this library. It is on that sum that we have acquired the following.

[Born in Chichester to Edward, knight bachelor, he makes a splendid promise of inheriting not only his father’s lands but also his considerable virtues. The Pembroke Muses will give a wealth of support for this judgment. For in their service, he has already attached himself to the first order of this college for two years, with all due observances. Unsatisfied with just this, he is striving to make his piety to Pembroke even plainer, and his service even more acceptable with his gifts. Thus we receive the following six books into our literary ranks, donated by him on 19 March, AD 1622.]

A citizen of Londen in the neighbourhood of Cheapside, by the sign of the Three Monks. He belonged to the society of Byssopolæ, known popularly as the Mercer’s Company.
He was a man of great character and piety, a brilliant worshipper of the Muses and the Discipline of Theology. By that token he was long friendly with our Doctors Beale, Wrenn and Lany.

He had two sons in this college, Roger the elder and Richard the younger. Both were from the famous order of Dr Watts’ students. Both were making a start in the Arts, and Richard was already among the Fellows of the College. On account of them, in gratitude to the College’s friendship to him, he made the following extraordinary gift as a testament to his charity. This gift, which cost some sixty pounds, was his offering to us on 28 May 1631.]
From the edition of William Cæsius, Amsterdam, 1622.

A citizen of London, and a distinguished admirer of Reverend Father Lancelot Andrewes, Bishop of Winchester. In that connection he was solicitous for the Glory of Pembroke, and thus embellished our library with the following gift in witness to his pious mind.

A man deemed worthy by the King, by the Church, and by us. He suffered much both at home and abroad for the sake of the King and the Church. Wishing everything for our own cause, he proves himself (to us and our posterity) extremely devoted to the name of Pembroke with the following gifts:
1,2 Monasticon Anglicanum. II Volumes. 8.17.26–27 | Wing D.2486.
London 1655 Vol. I Typis R. Hodgkinson
London 1661 Vol. II Typis A. Warren
Both volumes missing since the 1770s. Volume II returned by E. Stable in 1885.

A fellow and president of the College. A man of refined learning, he left £20 to us at his death for the purpose of buying books. This having been spent together with the rest of the college's money by the vice of the present time, it has left us with only the memory of so pious a benefactor on this blank page.

Once a Fellow of this College, Rector of the Diocese of Radwinter in London, in the county of Essex, Chancellor of the Cathedral of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Salisbury, and Chaplain to his Most Serene Royal Majesty. On the feast of the birth of John the Baptist, 1663, he gave:
Eiusdem, Thesauri Orthodoxæ Fidei, Libros V in linguam Latinam tralatos per Petrum Morellum. Genevæ apud H. E. Vignon 1592 8vo. 5.7.26.
Theophylacti Epistolas Græ. MS. Folio. LC.II.233. Not in James.
Vitas Barlaam & Josaphat Gr. MS. Fol. James 291.
[James also lists 288, a manuscript titled τοῦ σοφωτάτου Βαρλαὰμ λόγος περὶ τῆς τοῦ πάπα ἀρχῆς, as having come from this gift.]
Ailredum denique Abbatem Rievallensem, De Anima. MS. Folio. James 205.

But under the condition that when Thomas Bayly pays to the Master and Fellows of Pembroke Hall the £5 that he owes to the said Richard, the books shall be returned to the aforesaid Thomas. Other books, however, are to be acquired with that sum, for the use of the Library of Pembroke Hall. To which the said Richard Drake wishes and prays for all all happinesses from his heart.

Eldest son of Thomas, esq. of Great Witley in Wigorn county; not long ago a messmate of the fellows of this college. In witness of his singular piety towards his alma mater, of his warmth towards good letters, and of his care and devotion to the society of Pembroke, he gave £10 for the use of the library, from which the following books were bought:
Kirscheri Oedipus Ægiptiacus 4 Vol. Ex typo Vitamascardi. Rome 1652, 53, 54 fol. 8.8.29–32..
Ejusd. Obeliscus Pamphilius. Rome 1650 fol. Probably 8.2.24.
Ejusd. Musurgia universalis. Rome 1650 fol. LS (Mus.) e.6.21.
Ejusd. Ars Magna Lucis et umbræ. Sumptibus H. Scheus, Rome 1646 fol. 13.1.25.
Ejusd. Magnes; sive de Arte magnetica. B. Deursin & Z. Masotti, typis V. Mascardi. Editio tertia. Rome 1654 fol. 11.16.32.
Student, fellow, president, and master of the college; Archdeacon of St Alban, and treasurer of the Church of St Paul.

This man, extremely generous to his fellow Valencians, besides £100 for building new College buildings, and besides £10 for repairing already-erected buildings, left £100 in his will to increase the salary of the Librarian. He also left his entire library to the library of the College, in addition to £20 for acquiring some new book each year under his name.

Secretary to the most Serene Lord Thomas Bendish, who was ambassador to the Turks under King Charles II; then Consul at Smyrna to the English merchants. After his return, he was a rector in Helmingham in Suffolk. He gave [blank] for the use of the library, from which the following books were bought.

Thirty-nine come from the stack of paper that Wren originally used; the remaining fifty-nine were added, later ca. 1680]
A catalogue of manuscripts, which you will find collected separately in the last two cabinets.
The remaining 11 manuscripts are stored in a chest.
Class 2 of the twelfth cabinet contains printed books that have duplicates in the library.
Each book is assigned three numbers. The first indicates the cabinet, the second contains the class within that cabinet, and the third is the book's number within that class.
Now because there are sometimes many authors and books in the same codex, you will find an alphabatised list of authors at the end of this index.
